text:
- I'm Brian Cobb, the
Chief Innovation Officer
for the Cincinnati Northern Kentucky
International Airport.

The challenges that we
were trying to solve

with AWS Panorama and
our partner TaskWatch,
were to really understand the complexities
around the airport in real time
and ultimately get to a predictive state
with the high powered machine learning

and the analytics that come
along with this solution.

(gentle music)
(airplane whooshing)
Our most critical milestone

is to understand the
complexity that we came from
and where we are today.
Were originally a hub airport.
And a hub means 80% of our traffic,

roughly 4 million consumers
were coming through,

really from one aircraft to
another, they were connecting.
In an O and D market, origin, destination,

which is what CVG is now,
under that circumstance,

we actually have more than
double that consumer amount,
over 9 million customers

that are actually coming
through the front door.
So what does that imply?
All of those vehicles
that are actually dropping customers off
that just didn't exist previously.

So with our camera analytics
and the AWS Panorama product,

we're actually able to
take snapshots of vehicles

to determine what's actually
occurring in real time,
and send that to our public safety agents.

So that they can actually
approach a vehicle

and let that consumer
know it's time to move.
In the past, there was a perception issue.
Perception difference in time.

Now, it's a circumstance
where we can actually show

a timestamp of your actual
vehicle to let you know
you've exceeded the maximum time

that you can be permitted
on the curb front,
we actually need you to move along.
(airplane whooshing)
In an airport like ours,
really, the individuals that are touching

and handling that aircraft
are not necessarily

the airline employee,
it's a contract service.

So in that ombudsman environment,
like we're operating,

we find ourselves really
in between a contractor
and an airline tenant.
And under those circumstances,
what information that can we be providing

to both parties that were
actually influencing the outcome
of an effective aircraft term.

And really what that boils
down to is the camera system

looking at the aircraft in
real time and evaluating

our services occurring
as they're scripted.

And if they're not,
what is the implication

to that aircraft, either
running on time or running late?
And if it's running late,

how can we actually
prevent that from occurring
before it actually unravels in front of us

and hurts the overall
integrity of the operation?
So really, again, we're pursuing

what is it that we can be
doing and looking in advance
to prevent challenges from ever occurring,

and ultimately allow that
aircraft to depart on time,
just as you would expect.
(gentle music)
